Information to Electors.

The following is the qualification of electors as prescribed by the Parliament Act:

Every person qualified to vote at the election must be an elector of the constituency in which he resides, or a resident within the electoral district, and who has been registered as such for at least six months immediately preceding the election.

If any elector finds that his name is not included in the polling division to which he belongs, he may apply to the Returning Officer for a certificate of inclusion before the polling day, and if the same is granted, he may then vote.

If any elector finds that his name is not included in the polling division to which he belongs, he may apply to the Returning Officer for a certificate of inclusion before the polling day, and if the same is granted, he may then vote.

LATEST NOVELTIES IN TOYS,

AT COST FOR CASH.

JUST ARRIVED,

CHAS. MAIR'S WEST END STORE,

Nun's Veiling in Cream and Light Shades, Persian Parlor Rugs, Tapestry Carpets, Crimson Repos, Window Island in Black and Yellow, Door Matting, Crumpled Paper, Bedding, Chalkings, Empress Cloth in Black and Garnet, Fine Cretonnes, Ladies' Felt and Embroidered Petticoats, Ladies' Fancy Frillings, Beccio Veiling, Ladies' Silk Ties, Tinsel, etc., etc.

ALL AT LOW PRICES.

Also a large stock of Ready-made Clothing and Fresh Groceries, including Fancy Confectionery, Biscuits, Figs, Dates and Tinned Goods of all kinds. Inspection is solicited.

**ADDRESS**

To the Electors of Saskatchewan:

Gentlemen:

At the request of a number of friends in the District of Saskatchewan, I beg to offer myself as an eligible to your suffrages at the coming election as a member for the Federal Parliament.

Should I be returned as your representative I shall use every endeavor to secure the local interests of the District, and shall urge on the Government the necessity of pushing on Railway communication to Prince Albert, Battleford, and Saskatoon.

The building of a bridge across the South Saskatchewan River;

The granting of assistance to the railway to Hudson's Bay;

The fixing of wages for the laborers to all Appointments Board heads of Families born in the Territories between 1870 and 1885;

The recommendation of the permanent system by which the liquor question may be treated;

The speedy payment on a liberal scale of all just claims against the Government;

The procurement of seed grain free on account of the peculiar circumstances in which the settlers of this district find themselves;

The amendment of the Land Acts in such manner as to secure congratulation to the people;

The granting of positions under Government to local men;

The purchasing of supplies needed for public institutions situated in the district in which they are consumed;

The formation of a Legislative Assembly to deal comprehensively with the future of Saskatchewan; I appear to every elector in the district for support during the ensuing year.

I am, gentlemen,

Your obedient servant,

D. H. Macdonald.

**Avocats du District de Saskatchewan:**

Messieurs,

A la demande d'un nombre d'amis intéressés dans le District de Saskatchewan et d'un certain nombre de citoyens consentants, j'ose solliciter votre suffrage pour être élu pour le Parlement Fédéral.

Si j'étais élu, je ferai tout mon possible pour que le gouvernement fasse preuve de toute sa volonté pour obtenir l'établissement d'un pont sur la rivière Saskatchewan du Sud ;

La construction du chemin de fer de la baie au centre bis ;

La révisorisation de la base des salaires pour les travailleurs employés à tous les postes ;

La trêve des travaux de la voie de chemin neigeux ;

La révision des lois sur le montage de la Saskatchewan pendant cette période ;

La formation et la reconnaissance des positions au plus haut niveau ;

La création d'un conseil pour la gestion des ressources naturelles ;

La recommandation des lois relatives à la colonisation des territoires nouvellement colonisés.

Je serais honoré si vous prêtez une mains tendue à cette cause.

Cordialement,

[Votre signature]

---

**AVIS D'ÉLECTION**

District Electoral de Saskatchewan:

Savoir:

Un appel est donné au peuple de négocier des élections au cours du prochain mandat, après coup, pour la formation d'un Conseil pour administrer la Saskatchewan.

Par conséquent, je prie toutes les personnes qui ont voté non seulement pour leurs propres intérêts, mais aussi pour ceux des autres électeurs, de faire preuve de générosité et de voter pour moi lors de la prochaine élection.

N.B.- Le vote est obligatoire pour tous les citoyens admissibles âgés de 18 ans ou plus.

**Notice!**

Please take note of the changes in the School Districts which will take place on Thursday, the 24th Day of February.

For the purpose of borrowing the sum of thirty-three shillings sixpence from me, in order to pay the present rate of interest, the sum of twenty-eight shillings ninepence, the last day of the month, the rate of interest will apply from the 1st day next following the date of the interest then due.

The qualifications of voters shall be as stated in the rules laid down by the School Board of Education, 1885.

ELECTION NOTES.

Mr. Macdonald will leave for Portage la Prairie tomorrow evening, in company with Messrs. Hughson and Macdonald.

Mr. Lord will visit Bathurst town district. Messrs. Gray and Craig will also proceed to Bathurst and endeavour to make the election there for Lord.

A dispatch from Brandon states that Mr. Macdonald's majority will be over one hundred.

A number of men were seen digging holes on the night of the election, and escape was also dangling from a number of domiciles. It is supposed that the new king will try their strategies by buying themselves.

Mr. Lord left Brandon yesterday for St. Louis, where he held a meeting last night. He hopes the agreement with Mr. Macdonald will hold joint meetings, and will not break the peace. His colleagues would be there on the same day Mr. Gunn will meet him at night.

When the news arrived that the Commons had passed an amendment to the Constitution Act, Sir John Macdonald wrote to Sir Leonard Tilley that a great change in the situation was going to take place. The government was now obliged to act, and Sir Leonard Tilley would have been obliged to yield, but Sir John Macdonald would not have been able to do so. Sir Leonard Tilley would have been obliged to yield, but Sir John Macdonald would not have been able to do so.

A meeting was held at Brandon last night, and Sir John Macdonald spoke about forty people being present. Speeches were made by Edward Dickens on behalf of the Reformers, and Mr. Macdonald spoke on behalf of the Liberals. Mr. Macdonald stated that the government was opposed to any measure that would affect the interests of the province.

Mr. Macdonald will be in the North-West District next week.

Mail Contract.

For the last two years parties have been engaged in the struggle for the control of the Roman Catholic Church in Canada. The result of this struggle has been that the Roman Catholic Church in Canada is now under the control of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

It is reported that Mr. Macdonald will be in the North-West District next week.
